13.text:
Someone gets up at a TED Talk and says,
"Behold, we don't have to do it like this.

17.text:
I've got a better idea.
There's another way.

19.text:
There's another technology.
There's a new way of seeing the world."

22.text:
The new guys go, "Wow, that's fantastic.
We'll go out and create change."

26.text: You can't wait to go to your workplace

28.text:
or go back to the people
that you live with and say,

30.text:
"Rejoice my people.
There is a better way.

33.text: It doesn't have to be this way."

34.text:
You're expecting the whole world
to go, "Fantastic, it's going to change."

40.text:
You go, "Come on, we can do this,
we can totally do this."

42.text:
They go, "No. You know what?
Because we've done it before,"

45.text:
or "Now's not a good time,"
or "We haven't got the money,"

48.text:
or "It's been done",
"It's never been done."

50.text:
That's not the way we do things
around here. It's not part of the charter.

53.text:
It's traditional. It's complicated.
It's political."

55.text: Do you recognize any of these?

57.text:
Of course, they're
all different ways of saying this,

59.text: of saying, "It's not going to happen."

62.text:
What I've been doing -
I work in the innovation space,

64.text:
I'm interested in this wall,
and how do we get past this wall.

68.text:
How do we take our passion and our ideas
and actually make them happen?

71.text: I've been trying to figure out,

73.text:
what this wall is made of,
and how do we get past it?

75.text:
If we can't get past it, go under it,
go around it, or just smash through it.

79.text:
The first thing you need to know:
these aren't real reasons.

83.text:
That becomes pretty clear
because they're so easy to refute.

87.text:
If I say for example,
"It's always been like this",

91.text:
It means the problem
is older than you think it is.

93.text:
It's not an argument
for not changing it now.

96.text:
It's a reason why
we should've changed it 20 years ago.

99.text: When they say, "It's the same everywhere,"

101.text:
what they're really saying is the problem
is broader and wider than you think;

104.text:
it isn't an argument or not fixing it here
but an argument for fixing it everywhere.

108.text:
When they say for example,
"It's not in the budget,"

111.text:
it means we've spent the money
in the wrong places.

115.text: When they say, "It's not in the charter,"

117.text:
what they're saying is the people
who were supposed to provide the vision

120.text: weren't thinking as big as you.

122.text:
When they say, "It's political,"
what they're saying is,

125.text: "I've learned to keep my ideas to myself."

128.text:
When they say, "It's just traditional,"
what they're saying is,

131.text:
"Actually, I don't know
why we're doing this,

134.text: but it's always been that way."

138.text: The thing is they are so easy to refute.

141.text:
When they say things
like, "It's too complicated,"

144.text: you say, "I can make it simpler for you."

147.text:
When they say, "You know what,
it just sounds like it's too simple,"

150.text:
you say, "That's OK,
I'll make it more complicated."

153.text:
My favorite one, a friend of mine
got this one the other day,

156.text: "This isn't what we pay you to do."

159.text:
His answer was, "That's OK,
this one's a freebie."

163.text:
If these aren't the real reasons,
then what are?

No one will tell you
what the real reasons are,

I'm going to show you the seven
classic reasons why people resist change

176.text: and what to do about them.

to think about

"I'm scared of
the transition not the idea."

"I don't know how big a deal

"I feel like I have

The one that cracks me up,

Very often, when people

Let me take you

Every time something happens
or there's a change, there's

what's interesting about it,"

256.text:
or, "I just want to focus

258.text:
These people who've just been fired?
What do you think? The negatives.

Instead of trying to change their minds
to help embrace their change,

265.text: I just said, "How do you feel about it?"

268.text:
"I feel scared", "I'm angry,"

271.text: I let them talk for about 15 minutes,

273.text:
and everything that came out of them
was a variation on that same four.

276.text:
I'd write them down, and I say,
"Have you got anything new?"

281.text:
There was nothing else to say
about the negativity.

284.text:
Then they started saying,
"I knew this was happening.

287.text:
I've only been putting up
with this job out of sufferance.

290.text:
I need a good push, and is the best
that could've happened to me."

293.text:
They got there by themselves,
with me only ratifying their feelings.

297.text: I was just listening to how they felt.

298.text:
Then, before I knew it, they were
here, saying, "This was great.

302.text: I'll go back to study. I'll travel.

Why don't we build a little support group

All of them have got better jobs,

310.text: They went through this whole thing

of what's the negatives,

315.text:
If you've ever seen
a small child running and falling over,

318.text:
he doesn't know for a short while
whether it's a good thing or a bad thing.

322.text: They're not sure. Have you noticed?

323.text:
They just sit there in this neutral space
like, "OK, this is different."

328.text:
What will happen is,
if dad says, "That was funny,"

332.text: then the kid gets up and does it again.

334.text:
If mum runs up and goes,
"Oh, my darling, are you OK?"

336.text: the kid goes, "I don't think so."

340.text:
As children, we have this positive/
interesting/negative space.

This interesting space
is where the artist is,

346.text:
it's where the innovator is,
it's where the inventor is.

349.text:
They'll say, "This is unusual.
What can we do with this?"

352.text: As we get older we compress that space,

354.text:
and we see everything in terms
of this dichotomy between good and bad.

357.text: This is good, this is bad.

359.text:
Our default is to rate
every change as being bad.

362.text:
This is a way of people to understand,
to audit their emotions about this state.

"I'm scared of the transition.

I've realized the way we do things now has

The status quo is all of these things;
it is known, it is proven, it's familiar.

Sure it's insane,

396.text:
Whereas, what's the problem with B?

It's unproven, it's

In the unknown, the thing

This is the trick,

A long list of things

508.text:
and I suppose we can't cheat,

513.text:
Door number three are the things

In this case, it was get stuck

They can see the change's got edges to it.

People feel like they're

562.text:
The key to this is the difference
between authorship and ownership.

What we do is we say to people,

568.text:
Gosh, why aren't people

You've seen this happen.

574.text:

577.text:
You report to me, and by the way,

579.text:
It doesn't work.
What works is authorship.

582.text:
If you say, "Here's why we have to change.

586.text:
You tell me how. You tell me
how you're going to make it work."

590.text:
You empower them to design

593.text:
Suddenly, they're not responding
to change but taking control of change.

596.text:
Here's one of my favorite techniques
for this, called the renovator's delight.

600.text:
If you think about it,
have you ever renovated a house?

602.text:
What did you keep? What did you chuck?

We talk to organizations

Bored people want change.

I could be talking about

When I work with very cynical, closed

968.text:

973.text:
to lose a rare opportunity to make change

and risk disappointment

When you lay it out like that, the choice
